realized this precious opportunity,I later falter through delusion,When the time of death arrives,I shall be overcome with great sorrow.The unbearable fires of hell will burnMy body for a long, long time to come.Then the flames of remorse, equally torturous,Will surely consume my mind that abandoned bodhicitta vows.Having by rare coincidence obtained this extremely difficult-to-find human body—a precious foundation for spiritual benefit—Though I possess the wisdom to distinguish virtue from non-virtue,If I lead myself back to those same hell realms from which I once came,It is as though I've been bewitched, forsaking my connection to the Buddha.Like one bewildered by mantras,I am here bereft of mental discernment.I do not know by what affliction I am deluded;What dwells within me causing this loss of control?Enemies of hatred, craving, and the rest,Have no limbs, legs, and so forth,Not brave nor wise, yet somehowThey have made me their servant.While dwelling within my mind as unwelcome intruders,These enemy afflictions joyfully inflict their harm on me;To show patience toward such destroyers without angerIs misplaced tolerance, condemned by the Buddhas and noble ones.Even if all the gods and demigodsWere to rise against me as enemies,Even they would not be capableOf dragging me into the fires of Avīci hell.When these powerful enemies—my afflictions—arise,Even Mount Meru would leave not a trace of ash when consumed by them;I am cast in a single instant by these mighty foes of afflictions,Into that terrible Avīci hell.My affliction-enemies endureWithout beginning or end through boundless time;Unlike them, no other adversaries,However powerful, can last so long.When served with respect and provided what they need,Even ordinary enemies bring benefit and happiness.But when inner afflictions are indulged,They only cause repeated suffering and harm.Thus, when these continuous and ancient foes—afflictions that have been enemies since beginningless time without a moment's interruption, the sole source producing all streams of suffering—fearlessly dwell in my heart, how could I possibly find joy in saṃsāra?These afflictions, guardians of saṃsāra's three realms' prison,Act as executioners in the Reviving Hell and lower states.If they dwell in my mind, trapped in improper thought's attachment net,How could I find any physical or mental well-being?Therefore, until I have decisively conquered these enemies—the afflictions—In direct perception, I shall not abandon my diligence in this practice.Just as those inflated with pride and filled with anger at even slight offensesWill not sleep until they have defeated their adversary.Those afflictions—our enemies since birth, pitiable in their suffering from impermanence and deathWhen confronting them in battle, we must firmly resolve to destroy themEnduring the pain of countless arrows, spears, and weapon strikesWe never turn back until we accomplish our goal, no matter the hardships we faceThe constant causes of all suffering since beginningless time.When I strive to conquer these innate afflictions—my natural enemies.How could I possibly fall into despair over past failures or grow disheartened,Even when wounded by hundreds of hardships in this spiritual battle?If people proudly bear wounds inflicted by enemies without purposeAs if they were ornaments adorning their bodies,Then why should hardships not be welcomed as purifying aidsBy me, who strives diligently to achieve the supreme goal?Fishermen, butchers of low caste, farmers, and others like them,With minds fixed solely on their own meager livelihood,Enduring cold, heat, and other torments,Why then should I not bear suffering for the sake of establishing all beings in ultimate bliss?I vowed to liberate all beings throughout the ten directionsTo the farthest reaches of space from afflictions and karmaYet at the time of making this solemn pledge I myselfRemain not freed from these afflictionsNot knowing the measure of my own capabilitiesHow could such speech not be that of a madmanTherefore, to conquer afflictions that bind meI shall remain forever unwavering in this battleHere I shall deliberately cling to the antidotesAnd harbor enmity toward afflictions engaging them in battleSuch affliction-like mental states as theseAre exempt from abandonment when they serve to destroy afflictions.Let my intestines spill out, let my head fall to the ground—I would rather endure this bodily death than submit.But in no way shall I ever bow downTo the enemies of afflictions, which lead to endless suffering.Even if an enemy is banished from one's land,They may dwell in other regions, establish themselves there,And return once they've gathered strength anew—But the foe of afflictions works not in this way.Afflictions are abandoned by the eye of wisdom.When removed from my mind, where would they go?Where could they abide, then return to harm me?My dull intellect alone fails to make effort.Neither in objects, sense faculties, nor between them do afflictions dwell,Nor elsewhere—yet where do these beginningless foes reside that torment the entire world?These are mere illusions; dispel fear from your heart and directly confront them with wisdom's discerning effort.Why needlessly harm yourself in hell realms when understanding their empty nature sets you free?Having thus firmly resolved, I strive diligentlyTo accomplish the trainings as they have been taught.How can one afflicted with disease find freedom from illnessIf they disregard the physician's instructions about their medicine?This concludes the fourth chapter entitled 'Vigilance' apramāda from the Introduction to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life Bodhicaryāvatāra.One who wishes to protect the trainingShould guard the mind with vigilance.If this mind remains unguarded,The training cannot be maintained.When the elephant of the mind is left unrestrained,It causes harm like the torments of Avīci hell;But even a wild, intoxicated elephantDoes not inflict such suffering in this world.When the elephant of mindIs firmly bound with mindfulness' rope,All fears shall vanish,And every wholesome virtue shall come to hand.Tigers, lions, elephants and bears.Snakes and all who threaten as foes.Hell's guardians who bring future terror.Witches ḍākinīs and demons rākṣasas.Through binding this single mind,All sources of harm become restrained.Through taming this single mind,All dangers become pacified.Thus all fears and immeasurable sufferingsArise from the deluded mind alone,So taught the Buddha,Who speaks only truth.Who has purposefully created these weapons in the hells?Who has made the blazing iron ground?From where have those hosts of women arisen?All these arise from one's own negative mind alone.The Sage declared that all these various harmsArise from the evil mind itself;Therefore, in all three worlds,There exists no fear more terrifying than the mind.If liberating all beings from povertyIs truly the perfection of generosity,Yet many remain destitute even todayHow could the former Buddhas have perfected such giving?With all possessions including their fruits,To every sentient being with generous mind,The perfection of giving is declared;Therefore, this perfection is indeed mind itself.Where could fish and other beings be drivenSo that they would not be killedFrom attaining the mind of renunciationThe perfection of ethical discipline is explained.Ill-mannered sentient beings are as vast as space,It is impossible to subdue them all.But when the angry mind is conquered,It is as if all enemies have been vanquished.Where would one find enough leather to cover the entire surface of the earth.It would be impossible.However, with just the leather of a shoe sole,It is as if the whole earth has been covered.Just as I cannot ward off external things,I shall instead restrain my angry mind.What need have I for controlling others?With patience, my mind alone must be tamed.What fruit comes from a single, intense mind of clarity?Rebirth in the Brahma realm and similar states.Body and speech actions yield many fruits.With weak practice, this is not the case.All recitations and austerities,Though practiced over long spans of time,When performed with a mind distracted elsewhere,The Knower of Reality declares them purposeless.The supreme essence of Dharma. If one does not know this secret of the mind.Though seeking to attain happiness and overcome suffering.They wander pointlessly without purpose.Therefore, this mind of mine,I must well grasp with mindful awareness and carefully guard.Apart from the discipline of protecting the mind,What purpose do numerous external vows and practices serve?Just as one who dwells among the unrestrained,Vigilantly protects their wound with great care,Likewise, when living among those who provoke afflictions,One must always protect this vulnerable wound of the mind.If frightened by the slightest wound's pain,I guard that wound with diligent concern.When fearing mountains crushing in the hell of Saṃghāta,why wouldn't I protect my mind's wound from its outward-leaking harm?If one maintains such conduct,Whether dwelling among evil people,Or residing among women,The steadfast practitioner of discipline will not falter.Let my gains and honors freely perishMy body and livelihood likewise fadeOther virtuous deeds may also declineBut never shall my awakened mind deteriorateTo those who wish to guard their minds,I join my palms in earnest supplication:'With every effort, safeguard mindfulness,And introspective awareness'—I join my hands thus.Just as one afflicted by illnessIs powerless in performing all tasks,So too a mind disturbed by confusionLacks capacity for all virtuous activities.For one whose mind lacks vigilant awareness,Knowledge gained through hearing, contemplation, and meditation,Like water in a leaking vessel,Neither remains in memory nor yields meditation,This merit stems from the profound greatness of sentient beings themselves.Whatever merit arises from devotion and faith in the Buddha,That likewise manifests from the Buddha's own greatness.Through inherent Buddha-nature that fulfills dharma qualities,Thus they are considered equal in this regard.Yet none can match the BuddhasWith their infinite ocean of excellences.One who possesses the unique collection of supreme qualities.Even a tiny fraction of qualities seen in someone.For the purpose of honoring such a being.Even offering the three realms would be insufficient.The portion of causes for the supreme Buddha-dharma's arisingExists within all sentient beings as well.For this reason alone, in accordance with this aspect,Sentient beings should properly be objects of veneration.Furthermore, to those who have become our true friends without pretense,Who bestow immeasurable benefits upon all beings,Other than pleasing sentient beings,What greater way could there be to repay their kindness.Those for whose sake the Sage would sacrifice his body and enter the Avīci hell,to benefit them is to repay his kindness.Therefore, even toward those who cause great harm,one servant's nature toward these various masters.When the happiness of sentient beings brings joy to the Lords of Sages,And when harm to these beings causes the Perfect Ones to feel displeasure,By bringing joy to these beings, one makes the supreme offering that pleases all Lords of Sages.By causing harm to these beings, one has precisely and equivalently harmed the Sages themselves.Just as one whose body is ablaze on all sidesCannot find joy in any pleasures however desirable,So too when harm is done to sentient beings,The greatly compassionate ones cannot possibly be pleased.Therefore, I who have harmed beings,And thus displeased all those of great compassion,Today I openly confess each sin individually,For all displeasure caused, I beseech the Mighty Sages for patience.To please the Tathagatas,From this day forward, I firmly commit myself to becoming a servant of the world.Whether the masses strike me on the crown of my head with their feet,Or even kill me, I shall not be provoked; may the Protector of the World be pleased.All beings in this world have been made their own by those whose nature is compassion.There is absolutely no doubt about this.Indeed, these beings who appear in the form of sentient beings are none other than the protectors themselves.Why then should one not show reverence to them?This practice of patient endurance and showing respect toward beings truly pleases the Tathagatas Buddhas.This same practice accomplishes one's own purpose by accumulating merit.This patience and kindness toward beings dispels worldly suffering by enabling them to engage in virtuous actions.Therefore, I shall always diligently practice these three types of patience, pleasing all beings.Just as a royal official may oppress the common people, the far-sighted multitude, who discern future consequences, though fully capable, wisely choose not to retaliate.Since none from royal ranks acts alone,The king's power serves as their strength and force.Likewise, even the feeblest wrongdoerShould never be despised, harmed, or ignored.Thus the guardians of hell andThose with compassion are their forces.Just like commoners to a fierce king,One should please all sentient beings.What harm can an angry king truly inflict, |Can he cause the torments of hell, |That one will experience in future lives, |From causing distress to sentient beings. |Even if a king is thoroughly pleased,By delighting sentient beings,That which is attained—No king can bestow Buddhahood itself.That comes from pleasing sentient beings through patient care and benefit;Let alone future Buddhahood, why do you not see even in this very lifeThe prosperity that becomes a foundation for qualities, fame that spreads widely, and happiness arising from benefiting all?While wandering in saṃsāra, through patience one attains beauty with complete faculties and form,Freedom from illness, great renown, and abiding happiness,An extremely long life with sustained well-being,And the abundant prosperity of a universal monarch establishing virtue.From the Bodhicaryāvatāra Introduction to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life, this is the sixth chapter entitled 'Teaching on Patience' Kṣānti-pāramitā.Thus endowed with patience, one should strive with diligenceFor upon diligence, enlightenment rests as if in one's palmJust as without wind there can be no movementWithout diligence, neither merit nor wisdom can ariseDiligence is enthusiasm toward virtue.Let me explain its contrary aspects.Laziness is attachment to idleness and engagement in negative pursuits.And self-deprecation that undermines confidence in one's spiritual capacity.From savoring the pleasure of idle relaxationAnd the craving that seeks refuge in sleepFrom not being disheartened by saṃsāra's sufferingLaziness arisesEnsnared by the net of afflictions,And fallen into the trap of birth,You have entered the jaws of the Lord of Death.Why do you still not recognize this and act?Do you not see your own kindBeing slain, one after another?Yet still you sink into sleepLike an outcast and a buffalo.With all paths blocked completely from every direction,While under the vigilant gaze of Yama, Lord of Death,How can you take pleasure in eating?How can you sleep and how can you find delight?Since death will swiftly strike in this degenerate ageGather well the twin accumulations while you still canThough at the Lord of Death's approach you cast off slothWhat provisions for the journey can you secure when time has run outThis task remains unbegun though conceived in mind,That one barely started, this half-complete stands,When suddenly the Lord of Death arrives,'Alas! I am destroyed!' one thinks, virtues neglected while evils done.With face swollen by grief's force,Tears streaming from blood-red eyes, one sees hopeless relatives mourning the impending loss,While gazing upon the terrifying faces of Yama's messengers,Who come to lead one's soul to judgment based on karmic deeds.When tormented by memories of your own misdeeds,And hearing the hellish cries of torment,Your body soiled with filth as terror overwhelms you,What can you possibly do when bewilderment seizes your mind?Like a living fish writhing desperately on hot sand,You are gripped by fear even in this present life.What need is there even to speak of the inconceivableTorments of hell that await those who commit negative actions.When touched by hot water,You with tender, youthful skin cannot endure even this burning sensation.Yet having committed deeds that lead to hell realms,Why do you remain lazily at ease?Those lacking effort yet craving spiritual fruitsThe delicate ones who suffer countless harmsThough seized by death yet distracted like godsAlas! freedom from illness.Therefore, to eliminate the numerous sufferings of the three realms of samsara,One should endure minor discomforts of spiritual practice and austerities.The Supreme Physician does possibly be called a hand?Since fingers too are but an aggregation of joints,And joints themselves, when divided into their parts.Even parts when analyzed divide into particles smallAnd those particles too by six directional parts dissolveSince directional divisions lack any parts of their ownLike space itself no particle truly can beThus, what discerning person would feel attachmentTo forms that are like dreams upon examination?When the body exists merely by convention,What woman is there, and what man is there?If suffering inherently existed by its own nature,Why would it not impede those experiencing great joy?If pleasure had inherent existence,Why wouldn't delicious foods and other pleasantries delight those afflicted by grief and anguish?If, due to being overpowered by something stronger,That sensation remains unexperienced,How can that which lacks the inherent nature as an experienceBe considered a true sensation vedanā at all.Suffering exists in subtle form indeed,Is not its gross aspect merely removed?'If it's merely experienced as slight joy, different from that [pleasure],'Then that subtle [form] too belongs to pleasure itself.If when contradictory conditions arise,Suffering fails to manifest due to incomplete causes,Isn't it established that 'feeling' vedanā itselfIs merely conceptual imputation and fixation?For this very reason,This analytical investigation is cultivated as the antidote;From the field of discriminative examination ariseThe meditative absorptions that nourish yogis.If sense faculties and objects have space between,These partless entities can never truly meet.Without space between, as one they merge complete.Then which distinct thing could connect with which?There is no entry of one atomic particle into another.These particles are without space and equal in nature.Where there is no penetration, there can be no mixing.Where there is no mixing, there can be no contact.How can 'contact' be reasonably maintainedFor that which is utterly without parts?If you've seen something both partless and in contact,Demonstrate it.Consciousness, being formless, cannot logically have contact [with objects].[If it could, absurdities would follow, like contact between space and a hand, or with a barren woman's child.]Even collections [of sense faculty, object, and consciousness] lack true existence,As previously examined [when analyzing collections of parts and gross objects formed from particles].Thus, if contact has no inherent existence,How could feeling truly arise from anywhere?Why this exhaustion?Who could be harmed, by what, and how?When there is no inherently existing experiencer,And sensation too has no intrinsic existence,Having seen this state of emptiness,O craving, why do you not shatter?Seeing and touchingPossess a nature like dreams and illusions.Since they arise simultaneously with mind,Feelings cannot truly be perceived by it.Feelings from past or future momentsAre remembered only, not directly experiencedA feeling cannot experience its own nature—a contradictionNor can another truly experience it—all sensations lack inherent existenceThere is no experiencer whatsoever,Therefore, sensation itself cannot truly exist.In this selfless collection of five aggregates,How could such a sensation cause harm?The mind does not abide in the sense faculties.Nor in forms and other objects nor in the space between.Neither within the body's core nor in its outer parts is consciousness found.Nowhere else can it be discovered at all.That which exists neither within the body nor elsewhere,Neither mixed with nor separate from it anywhere,Such a mind is utterly non-existent in essence empty yet luminous.Therefore sentient beings are by their very nature primordially in parinirvāṇa.If consciousness exists prior to its object of knowledge,Upon what object does it inherently focus to arise?If consciousness exists simultaneously with its object of knowledge,Upon what object does it inherently focus to arise?If the object of knowledge were to exist after,Then from what would cognition arise?Thus, the arising of all phenomenaCannot be ascertained.If conventional reality with its births, cessations, comings, and goings lacks inherent existence,How then could the two truths possibly exist?If conventional reality exists merely through others' mental imputations,How could sentient beings ever transcend conceptual elaboration and pass beyond sorrow?This conceptual fabrication belongs to others' mindsBut in one's own conventional reality it does not existIf after attaining nirvana one ascertains it exists then it existsIf not then conventional reality itself is entirely non-existentConceptualization and the conceptualized object—These two mutually depend on one another.Based on what is conventionally renowned in the world,All analytical examinations are expressed.When, by means of analytical wisdom,One examines phenomena for inherent existence,Then that very analytical wisdom itself,Because it too requires examination, leads to infinite regress.When one thoroughly examines what is to be analyzed,The analyzing mind finds no inherent basis to rest upon;Without foundation, it does not arise—This is what is declared nirvana.For one who maintains both object and cognition truly exist,Their position is indeed extremely untenable.If objects are established through cognition's power,What grounds cognition's own existence?If knowledge depends on objects known,What basis have these objects on their own?If both exist through mutual dependence,Neither can be established.If without a son one cannot be a father,From where, prior to the father, would a son arise?Without a son, there is no father;Thus both lack inherent existence.A sprout arises from a seed,That very seed is understood through it,Consciousness arises from objects of knowledge,Why is their existence not understood?Through a cognition distinct from the sprout,One understands that 'a seed exists.'By what means is the existence of that cognition known,By which that object of knowledge is comprehended?Through perception and valid means, the world directly observesThat all effects arise from their particular causes;The diverse forms of lotus stems and similar thingsEmerge at specific times from corresponding causal distinctions.What creates these diverse distinctions among causes? From the patterns established by prior causes alone.Why does each cause produce its specific effect?From the intrinsic power of its causal lineage.If Īśvara is the cause of the world,Then pray tell, who exactly is this Īśvara?If you say 'the elements,' indeed, we agree,But why exhaust oneself over mere names?However, elements like earth are multiple entities,impermanent, devoid of conscious movement, not divine,things that can be trampled upon, and impure.For these reasons, they cannot be Īśvara.Neither space nor God can be the creator,since space is inert and lacks agency.Nor can it be the Self, as this has already been refuted previously.And what is the use of claiming that the inconceivable is the creator?What exactly does he wish to create?If the self—surely that is eternal,As are earth and such elements, and Īśvara's own nature.Knowledge arises from its objects.From beginningless time, suffering and joy arise from karma alone.Speak what specific effect has been created by Ishvara.If the cause itself has no beginning whatsoever,How could the results ever have a point of origin.Why does [Ishvara] not constantly produce effects?Since he does not depend on other conditions.If nothing exists that is not created by him,Upon what could this [creator] possibly depend?If [Īśvara/God] depends on a collection of causes and conditions,it is this collection that is the true cause, not Īśvara himself.When the collection of causes and conditions is present, Īśvara has no power to prevent the result from arising.And without those causes and conditions, Īśvara has no power to produce the result.If Īśvara creates unwillingly,He falls under others' power.If willingly, he's caught by desire's hook.How can one who acts dependently be the Supreme Lord?Those who maintain that atoms are permanent,They, too, have been refuted before.The Sāṃkhyas assert primordial nature pradhānaIs eternal and the cause of the world.Sattva, rajas, and tamas—the three guṇas—When in perfect equilibrium,Are declared to be pradhāna, the singular permanent unconscious primordial causal substanceWhen in disequilibrium, they produce transformations through mahat, ahaṃkāra, and the sixteen categories.For one primordial substance pradhāna to possess three distinct naturesIs logically impossible; therefore, such a singular entity cannot exist.Similarly, the qualities guṇas themselves cannot truly exist either,For each quality individually manifests threefold as 'quality containing qualities.'Without the three guṇas, sound and other sense-elementsWould be impossible to exist, far removed from realityAnd in insentient objects like clothingPleasure and similar experiences cannot possibly arise.If things exist as having happiness as their cause,Haven't such entities been proven ultimately non-existent?Your view makes happiness itself the cause,Yet from this, cloth cannot arise, nor can happiness from cloth.From cloth and such pleasure and such sensations ariseIn their absence such pleasures cannot existAnd the permanence of pleasure and other qualitiesAt no time is it ever observed by any valid meansIf pleasure and such truly manifest as inherently existent,Why is their experience not continuously apprehended?If that very same [pleasure] transforms to become subtle,How can a single entity be both coarse and subtle?When gross form transforms to subtle,Such gross and subtle states are impermanent.Likewise, for all phenomena in existence,Why not accept their impermanence as evident?If corporeality is not distinct from pleasure,Then clearly pleasure is impermanent.If you hold Nothing arises from non-existence,For what doesn't exist lacks causal power.Even against your will, you've already concededThat manifestation arises newly from non-existence.If effects dwell within their causes, |One who eats food would be consuming impure substances. |With the price paid for cloth, |Purchase cotton seeds and wear them. |If the world fails to see due to delusion,Then even those who know realityThat knowledge exists in worldly beings as well,Yet why don't they see effects hidden in their causes?If worldly perception is deemed to lack validity,Then even clear perception of manifested forms cannot be true.If valid cognition is not truly valid,Would not what it measures prove false?Therefore, in the ultimate sense, emptiness of phenomenaBecomes untenable.Without engaging with a fabricated entity,One cannot apprehend its non-existence.Therefore, whatever entity is false and impossible,Its non-existence too is clearly false.Therefore, when in a dream one's son has diedThe conceptual fabrication 'he does not exist'Obstructs the conceptual fabrication 'he exists'Yet that too is utterly falseTherefore, through thorough analysis,Nothing whatsoever exists without a cause;Nor does anything inherently abideIn conditions, whether separate or combined.It neither comes from elsewhere,nor does it abide, nor does it go.How is that which the deluded take to be realany different from an illusion?Examine what is conjured by magical illusion,And what is manifested through causal factors,From where do they come,And where do they go? Investigate this thoroughly.Whatever appears in the presence of certain causesAnd is not seen when those causes are absentIs artificially constructed similar to a reflectionHow could such a thing possess inherent existenceFor an inherently existent entity,What need is there for a cause?And if that entity is utterly non-existent,What need is there for a cause?Even with a hundred million causes assembled,That which is non-existent cannot be transformed into causal existence.How could something, while in a state of non-existence, become an entity?And what other thing could transform into a real entity?If when non-existent an entity lacks inherent capacity to exist.At what moment could this entity ever manifest as real.Without an entity first arising into existence.It cannot separate from its contradictory state of non-existence.If not free from non-existence,No possibility for existence can arise.Nor does what exists transform to non-existenceFor this would entail the absurd consequence of dual intrinsic nature.Thus there is no cessationNor are there inherently existing phenomenaTherefore all these worldsAre eternally unborn and unceasedAll beings and existences are like dreams in nature;When analytically examined, they resemble plantain trees;Between nirvana and samsara,In ultimate reality, there exists no difference whatsoever.Thus, in all phenomena that are empty of essence,What could truly be gained? What could truly be lost?By whom could one be honored?What could truly be despised?From where do happiness and suffering truly arise?What inherently exists to be liked or disliked?When investigating their ultimate nature,Who is the one who craves, and what could be craved?Upon analysis, this world of living beings.Who truly dies here.Who will come to be, who has ever been.What relative or friend exists.All phenomena are like spaceThis I and those like myself should fully graspThose who seek merely their own happinessThrough causes of fighting and attachmentAgitated by conflicts yet delighting in fleeting joys,Enduring grief, exhaustion, and disputes,Mutually cutting and piercing each other,Those survive with great hardship through misdeeds.Coming time and again to fortunate rebirth,Having enjoyed numerous pleasures,Upon death they fall into the lower realms,Where intense, prolonged, and unbearable suffering endures.In cyclic existence's three realms precipices of suffering aboundThere ultimate reality is not found only false conceptions unsoundSince mutual contradiction between emptiness-insight and entity-grasping standsThroughout samsara's ocean of pain true reality makes no demandsThere, incomparable and unbearableOceans of suffering extend beyond limits.There, beings possess such little strength,And there, life itself is indeed brief.Even in this life, our time is consumed byMaintenance of survival and health, hunger and exhaustion,Sleep and various afflictions, and likewiseAssociation with childish people—all meaningless pursuits.Life swiftly passes without virtuous purposeDiscriminating wisdom that perceives emptiness is exceedingly rareAnd even with fortunate conditions the samsaric habits of distraction flowHow could there be a method to reverse what has been practiced?There, too, into the great lower realms,Māra strives to cast beings down.There, wrong paths abound,And doubt is difficult to overcome.Again, precious leisure is exceedingly difficult to find.The arising of a Buddha is most rare to encounter.The flowing rivers of afflictions are nearly impossible to overcome.Alas, how beings move endlessly from one suffering to another.Alas! How utterly pitiable are these beings who, swept in suffering's flood of karma and afflictions,Fail to see their own desperate plight, mistaking pain for joy,And cling to samsara even while mired in such extreme distress!Some repeatedly batheAnd repeatedly enter fire,Thus in extreme sufferingThey dwell, yet delude themselves with happiness.Thus, for those who live in careless indulgence,Unlike true Arhats, acting as if exempt from aging and death,First death strikes—inevitable, without escape or remedy—Then unbearable torments await in the lower realms, perpetuating the cycle of suffering.When will I bring peace to those tormented by the fires of sufferingWith showers of provisions and happiness-giving resourcesBorn from the clouds of my meritPacifying their painWhen shall I, through wisdom free from all reference points,With reverence accumulate merit beyond conceptualizing doer, deed, and object,Then teach emptiness—the ultimate antidote—with compassionTo those who suffer in saṃsāra through grasping at inherent existence?Thus concludes the ninth chapter on the Perfection of Wisdom Prajñāpāramitā from the 'Introduction to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life' Bodhicaryāvatāra.Through the virtue of my contemplation onThis 'Entering the Bodhisattva Way,'May all beings throughout spaceBe adorned with Bodhisattva conduct.In all directions, wherever they may be,Those afflicted with bodily and mental suffering,May they, through my merit,Obtain oceans of happiness and joy.Throughout the endless expanse of saṃsāraMay these beings never fall from happinessMay all wandering beings attain without interruptionThe supreme bliss of bodhisattvas in non-abiding nirvāṇaIn all the world systems throughout existence,Whatever hell realms may be found therein,May all embodied beings there,Be reborn in Sukhāvatī and rejoice in its perfect bliss.May those suffering from cold attain warmth. Through the boundless rivers of waterThat flow from the great clouds of bodhisattvas,May those suffering from heat be cooled.May forests of razor-leaf treesBecome for them a Nandana garden's splendorAnd may the cotton trees of Mount ŚālmaliTransform into wish-fulfilling trees that grant all dharma desires.May blue teal, ruddy shelduck, swans, and other birds,Become beautiful with their melodious calls!With lakes rich in lotus fragrance,May regions of hell become delightful!May those heaps of burning coals become piles of precious gems.May the scorching earth transform into a crystal floor.May the crushing mountains that tear apart beings' fleshBecome magnificent offering palaces filled with Sugatas.May the rain of burning embers, heated stones, and weapons' downpourFrom this day forward transform into showers of blossoms.May the mutual combat with weaponsFrom today onward become merely flower-play.Submerged in the deceptive, fathomless burning river,With flesh dissolved, their bones white as kunda flowers,By the power of my merit, may they attain divine embodiment,And dwell with heavenly maidens in the gently flowing waters.Why do Yama's minions, crows, and terrifying vultures suddenly become frightened here?As darkness disperses in all directions and joy arises, may they wonder, 'Whose benevolent power is this?'Looking upward into the sky, may they behold the blazing Vajrapani wielding his vajra,And may they be freed from negativities through devotion's power and accompany him.A shower of lotus blossoms mixed with fragrant waters falls,Instantly quenching hell's burning coals with hissing sounds,'What is this?' wonder the beings, suddenly filled with unexpected bliss,May those suffering in hell behold the Lotus-Handed Lord of Compassion.Come quickly, brothers! Cast aside your fears and hasten here to us!By his power, all our hellish sufferings have vanished, and powerful waves of joy now flow within us.The awakened mind of bodhicitta has arisen in him, along with compassion that protects all beings without exception—the mother of universal salvation.For a radiant youth with five topknots adorned with a jeweled crest has arrived among us—some fearless-making Mañjuśrī.Behold him, his lotus feet worshipped by the crowns of hundreds of gods.His eyes moist with compassion, his head showered with blossoms.Dwelling in magnificent multi-storied palaces, with thousands of goddesses singing hymns.Upon seeing such a Mañjuśrī before them, may the agonizing cries of hell beings now transform.Thus, through my virtuous roots, may Samantabhadra and otherBodhisattva clouds free from obscurations, with their bliss andCooling, sweet-scented rain showers falling down to be seen,Cause those beings in the hells to truly rejoice.May animals be free from the fearOf eating one another.Like the humans of Uttarakuru,May all hungry ghosts experience happiness.From noble Avalokiteshvara, Lord of Compassion'sFingers, toes, and every pore flows sweet cooling nectar streams.May hungry ghosts be satisfied,And bathing in this nectar, be forever cooled.May the blind see forms with their eyes,May the deaf always hear sounds.Like the goddess of illusion,May pregnant women give birth without harm.May the naked receive divine garments of finest quality,May the hungry obtain nourishing food of a hundred flavors,May the thirsty find pure water of eight excellent qualities,May the parched enjoy divine nectar and sweet, delicious drinks.May the poor obtain wealth.May those in grief and suffering find joy.May the despondent be revived in spirit,And attain perfect, unwavering stability.May all sentient beings afflicted with illnessSwiftly be freed from their sufferingMay all maladies—both physical and mental—without exceptionNever arise again throughout all world systems by the power of this virtue.May those terrified become fearless.May those bound be liberated.May the weak become endowed with strength.May hearts grow tender toward one another.May all travelers, wherever they may journey,Find every direction—east, west, north, and south—auspicious and filled with good fortune! Whatever purpose drives them forward—be it wealth, trade, or spiritual quest—May it be accomplished without effort, as if the goal itself dissolves distance to meet them!May those embarking on boats and great shipsFulfill their quests for precious gems and treasuresSafely reach the shore, free from stormy winds and water perilsAnd rejoice with parents, relatives, and friends in festive celebration.May those who wander lost on sorrowful paths astray,Find companions who will guide them on their way,May they journey free from thieves, tigers and all fears,Proceeding onward without weariness or tears.In remote monasteries and wild perilous places,For children, the elderly and those without protection,For those asleep, intoxicated or thoroughly overcome by drink,May the divine guardians offer their vigilant safekeeping.Freed from the eight states without leisure for DharmaEndowed with steadfast faith, discerning wisdom, and loving compassionPerfected in pure sustenance and virtuous conductMay beings always remember their previous lives.May all possess inexhaustible treasuries like the sky-treasury meditation.Free from disputes and the toil of vigilance, may all beings—even the marginalized—enjoy their resources with perfect autonomy,Unharmed by enemies and spirits, using their abundance with wisdom and compassionFor dharma practice and others' welfare.May beings of little splendor who are overshadowed by othersBecome endowed with great majesty, free from others' contempt. May ascetics whose forms have grown ill-shaped through austeritiesBe blessed with the perfection of beautiful physical appearance.May all women in the world,Attain the masculine form. May those of lowly birth rise to higher status,And having attained elevation, may their pride be thoroughly vanquished.Through this merit of mine,May all sentient beings without exceptionAbandon all negative actions completely,And always engage in virtuous conduct.May we never be separated from bodhicitta.Be devoted to bodhicarya, the conduct of enlightenment.Be thoroughly embraced by all the Buddhas.And abandon all Māra's activities.May all sentient beingsPossess immeasurable, boundless lifespans.May they continuously dwell in perfect happiness, abundant prosperity, and complete freedom from suffering,And may even the very concept of death disappear entirely from their existence.May these be wish-fulfilling trees' pleasure gardens.Buddhas and the Buddha's children Bodhisattvas,Who captivate beings with the melodious proclamation of the Dharma,May they fill all directions.May the ground in all directions remain free from gravel and other impediments,Level like the palm of a hand, made of luminous, pure lapis lazuli,Naturally soft and smooth to the touch.Throughout all the maṇḍalas of assemblies—in monasteries, regions, and sacred places—May numerous bodhisattvas, with their own excellences, adorn the surface of the earth, and long remain present.May all embodied beings and birds,And all trees and rays of light,And even from the vast sky itself, the sound of Dharma,Continuously hear the unceasing.May they continually meet with the BuddhasAnd with the Buddha's sons, the bodhisattvas.Through infinite clouds of offerings,May they make offerings to the supreme guides of all wandering beings.May the gods, through our virtuous deeds, send rain in due season,May harvests be abundant, creating favorable conditions for Dharma practice. May the king rule righteously according to Dharma principles. May the world flourish—both the environment and all beings within it.May medicines of all types be endowed with power,May the recitation of secret mantras yield their intended results.May ḍākinīs, rākṣasas, and so forth,Become filled with compassionate minds.May no sentient being suffer pain.May none commit sinful actions or evil deeds.May none experience fear or be despised by others.May no one's mind ever fall into distress.May monasteries housing the Tripitaka flourish,adorned with study and memorized recitation. May the Sangha always remain harmonious,and may their aims be fully accomplished.May monks who seek the threefold training obtain outer, inner, and secret seclusion.Having abandoned all distractions,May they meditate with enthusiastic hearts on profound truth, cultivating minds of perfect pliancy and workability.May the bhikṣuṇīs be endowed with robes, food, and requisites,Free from quarrels among themselves and harm from others.Likewise, may all who have entered the renunciant pathMaintain their moral discipline completely unbroken.May I, disheartened by my moral failings,Always strive to exhaust negative deeds through confession and restraint.May I attain fortunate rebirth,And there, may my spiritual vows remain unbroken and my heart free from pride.May the scholars, versed in the five fields of knowledge and three baskets of teachings, be honored; May they obtain alms food, robes, bowls, and other monastic necessities;May their mental continuum be thoroughly purified of pride, jealousy, contempt, criticism of other traditions, and moral breaches; May their fame spread in all directions as learned and disciplined ones who discern what to adopt and abandon from the Victorious One's teachings that bring benefit and happiness.Without experiencing the suffering of lower realms,And without having to undertake difficult austerities,With a divine body that surpasses even the gods,May they attain the state of Buddhahood swiftly.May all sentient beings repeatedly make offeringsTo all the perfectly Awakened Ones throughout the ten directionsThrough the inconceivable bliss of Buddhahood, transcending worldly pleasureMay they always abide in abundant supreme happiness.May the aspirations of the bodhisattvas,For the temporary and ultimate benefit of wandering beings be fulfilled exactly as they intend;May whatever these compassionate protectors have in mind,Be bestowed upon all sentient beings, just as they envision.May the Pratyekabuddhas attain happiness,And may the Śrāvakas likewise be happy.Through the grace of Mañjuśrī,Until I attain the Ground of Perfect Joy,May I always remember my past lives,And obtain the perfect discipline of renunciation.May I sustain myself even with simple alms food, while maintaining strength and vitality for practice.In all future lifetimes until attaining Buddhahood, may I obtain perfect conditions for dwelling in solitude—with outer, inner, and secret seclusion fully accomplished.Whenever I wish to behold,Or desire to ask even the smallest point,May I see that very protector Mañjunātha,Without any obstacles.Throughout the ten directions to the limits of space,For the purpose of accomplishing the welfare of all sentient beings,Just as Mañjuśrī conducts himself with perfect wisdom,May my conduct become exactly like that.For as long as space endures,And as long as sentient beings remain,Until then, may I too abide,To dispel the sufferings of all beings.Whatever suffering exists among beings in all realms including the hells,May all of it ripen upon me.Through the aspirations and accumulated merit of the noble bodhisattva sangha,May all beings enjoy happiness and well-being.The sole medicine for all beings' suffering.The source of all happiness.May the Dharma—both scriptural and realized—Long endure with generous patronage and reverence.Through whose grace a virtuous mind arises,I bow to Mañjughoṣa Gentle Voice.Through whose kindness I have flourished,I pay homage to the Virtuous Friend kalyāṇamitra.This concludes the tenth chapter, entitled 'Dedication of Merit,' from the Bodhicharyāvatāra Entry into the Bodhisattva's Way of Life.Here ends the Bodhicharyāvatāra, composed by Ācārya Śāntideva.The Indian preceptor Sarvajñadeva and the great translator Bande Paltsegs collated the text with a Kashmiri manuscript and established a definitive edition.Subsequently, the Indian preceptor Dharmaśrībhadra and the great translators Bande Rinchen Zangpo and Śākya Lodrö corrected and retranslated [the text] in accordance with a manuscript from Central India and its commentary, thereby establishing an improved definitive edition.At a later time, the Indian preceptor Sumatikīrti and the great translator monk Loden Sherab meticulously corrected and retranslated [the text], thereby establishing a superior and thoroughly refined definitive edition.

incipit_title.en: The Way of the Bodhisattva Word by Word

Tibetanབྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའི་ → of the Bodhisattvaསྤྱོད་པ་ → Way/Conductལ་ → toའཇུག་པ། → Guide/Enter intoསངས་རྒྱས་ → Buddhasདང་ → andབྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ → Bodhisattvasཐམས་ཅད་ → allལ་ → toཕྱག་འཚལ་ལོ། → scriptureམདོར་བསྡུས་ → concisely/brieflyནས་ → fromནི་ → emphasis markerབརྗོད་པར་བྱ་ → shall explainསྔོན་ཆད་ → before/previouslyམ་བྱུང་བ་ → has not occurred/happenedཡང་ → also/evenའདིར་ → hereབརྗོད་ → to say/expressམེད་ → is not/have notསྡེབ་སྦྱོར་ → composition/prosodyམཁས་པ་ → skilled/expertཡང་ → alsoབདག་ལ་ → in me/Iཡོད་མིན་ཏེ་ → do not possessདེ་ཕྱིར་ → thereforeགཞན་དོན་ → benefit of othersབསམ་པ་
